_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Plan is being resubmitted to reflect recent changes to the facility's operations.  The Plan was previously revised in accordance with the requisite 5-year update, as well as to address additional data elements required to be included in all RMPs by June 21, 2004 per USEPA rule changes. The facility ceased storing regulated substances over threshold quantities and therefore submitted a Deregistration Notice on November 25, 2009. This resubmission is being filed as a result of the facility's operations review programs indicating that a regulated substance, peracetic acid, is now being stored above reporting threshold quantities.



1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Chicagoland Warehouse and Transportation, Inc. - Bridgeview is committed to employee, public, and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as hazardous materials segregation procedures, material handling equipment maintenance, and employee training associated with storage of hazardous materials at our facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.



2.  The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled

We have one (1) regulated substance present at our facility:  Peracetic Acid.



We have varying inventories for this chemical.  Peracetic Acid is a component of several customer-packaged materials that we store in our warehouse.



3.  The Worst Case Release Scenario and the Alternative Release Scenario, including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for reported scenario.

The worst case release scenario incorporates 3,000 pounds a peracetic acid acid released on the loading dock on a hot day. There are no mitigation measures assumed in this scenario. The alternative release scenario assumes a forklift collision with the totes, which are stacked two-high. As a result, two of th

e totes fall and their bladders rupture, producing an indoor release of 6,000 pounds of peracetic acid. 



4.  The General Accidental Release Prevention Program Level 3 and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps.

Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our stationary source.



Process Safety Information

Chicagoland Warehouse and Transportation, Inc. maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards (MSDS) for the regulated substance.



Process Hazard Analysis

Our facility conducted a study to ensure that hazards associated with our warehousing process were identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out this analysis was Hazard and Operability Analysis, guide word format.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis were addressed in a timely manner.



Operating Procedures

For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, Chicagoland Warehouse and Transportation, Inc. maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as segregation and storage procedures, use of forklifts, loading and unloading, examination of damaged containers, labeling of containers, and bracing, stacking and handling damaged containers.



Training

Chicagoland Warehouse and Transportation, Inc. has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided on an yearly basis and more frequently as needed.



Mechanical Integrity

Chicagoland Warehouse and Transportation, Inc. performs maintenance checks on forklift equipment to ensure proper operations.  Materials handling equipment examined by these checks include forkl

ifts.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



5.  Five-year Accident History

Chicagoland Warehouse and Transportation, Inc. has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.  There has been no accidental release during this period.



6.  Emergency Response Plan

Chicagoland Warehouse and Transportation, Inc. carries a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response, including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, and notification of local emergency response agencies and the public.



To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our warehousing process that would require a modified emergency response.
